guide.title: x86 Release Notes for Gentoo Linux 2004.0

body.p: Gentoo Linux is a community driven project commited to producing high quality opensource software. These release notes for Gentoo Linux 2004.0 summarize important package updates, security updates, and many other changes that have happened since Gentoo Linux 1.4.

ul.li: 3. Upgrading from previous versions of Gentoo Linux

body.p: Gentoo Linux 2004.0 contains security updates to address GLSAs (Gentoo Linux Security Advisories) numbered 200308-01 to 200402-07.
Individual GLSAs can be referenced by going to http://www.gentoo.org/security/en/glsa/glsa-$x.xml, and substituting $x with the desired GLSA number.
For more information, please consult the the gentoo-security mailing list archive.

tr.ti: Errors at boot about not being able to umount /dev.
SMP kernel does not recognize USB keyboards
There is a bug in the LiveCD SMP kernel that prevents this. Use a PS/2 keyboard or different kernel if possible. This will be fixed for 2004.1
Some NForce2 based boards may not display the bootsplash graphics properly.
Boot using the gentoo-nofb or smp-nofb kernels.

body.p: Coreutils is now available in Version 5.0.91-r4 with ACL patches.
The Portage version included in this release is 2.0.50-r1 and the ChangeLog can be found via our online CVS repository.

ul.li: Genkernel has been updated. Its behaviour is different to previous versions in previous releases.

body.p: Gentoo Linux 2004.0 on deprecates all single arch installation manuals in favor of the Gentoo Linux Handbook. The Gentoo Linux Handbook offers the most up-to-date information on all aspects of the Gentoo Linux installation process.

chapter.title: Upgrading and Installation of Gentoo Linux 2004.0

body.p: The entire Gentoo Linux installation process is documented in the Gentoo Handbook. Each architecture offers two CDs; the first one being a "universal" bootable LiveCD that contains a generic stage1 tarball, stage3 tarballs for each supported subarch, and the necessary distfiles needed to install a complete Gentoo Linux system without a network connection. In addition the to the "universal" bootable LiveCD, each architecture offers a second non-bootable LiveCD which contains precompiled binaries of popular programs such as XFree86, KDE, and GNOME optimized for a specific subarch, such as athlon-xp. At minimum, you will need the universal LiveCD to boot your machine to install Gentoo. Use of the second LiveCD is not necessary, although it may speed up your installation time considerably.

There are several kernels to choose from when using a Gentoo LiveCD to boot your machine. The two main choices, gentoo and smp boot your machine into either uniprocessor or multiprocessor (SMP) mode, respectively. The other two options, gentoo-nofb and smp-nofb boot your machine into uniprocessor or multiprocessor mode without console framebuffer support.

If you already have a working installation of Gentoo Linux (Version 1.4) there is no need to reinstall. You will automatically get Gentoo 2004.0 if you sync your Portage tree and run emerge --update world. If you still have an installation with a Gentoo 1.2 profile it might make sense -- in some cases -- that you do a new installation.

There is also the possibility to update your system to a 1.4 profile from which you -- as already stated -- can easily get to Gentoo 2004.0. This update includes recompiling of glibc and some essential system packages; it will take a very long time (possibly longer as a complete re-installation) and it might also fail. So if you still have an installation with a Gentoo 1.2 profile, it's your decision wether you update or reinstall.
